definitions: experience thoughts, images, and sensations during sleep in the mind
contemplate the possibility of doing something or wish for something to happen
examples: I dream about flying almost every night
Children often dream vivid and colorful dreams
She dreams of becoming a famous author someday
They dream about traveling the world together

definitions: move someone or something from one place, person, or position to another
make over the possession or control of property, rights, or responsibilities
examples: The company will transfer him to the London office
Please transfer the files to the new computer
They decided to transfer ownership of the house
She transferred her shares to her children

definitions: use offensive or obscene language, especially to express anger or frustration
make a solemn statement or promise undertaking to do something or affirming truth
examples: He tends to swear when he's really angry
Please don't swear in front of the children
I swear I didn't take your keys
She swore to tell the truth in court

definitions: use or expend carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose
examples: Don't waste water during the drought
He wasted his inheritance on gambling

definitions: make or become less tense, anxious, or stressed by resting or engaging in enjoyable activity
make a rule, restriction, or policy less strict or severe
examples: Try to relax and enjoy your vacation
A hot bath helps me relax after work
The school relaxed its dress code policy
They relaxed the rules for the weekend

definitions: have an obligation to pay or repay money to someone
have a moral obligation to give someone gratitude, respect, or duty
examples: I owe the bank twenty thousand dollars
She still owes me fifty dollars
We owe our success to hard work
I owe you an apology for my behavior

definitions: make a thorough or dramatic change in form, appearance, or character of something
examples: The renovation will transform this old building completely
Technology has transformed how we communicate

definitions: leave a place, person, or thing permanently and completely, especially when in difficulty
cease to support or look after someone or give up an activity or belief completely
examples: They had to abandon their car in the snow
The crew abandoned the sinking ship
He abandoned his dreams of becoming an actor
Never abandon hope in difficult times

definitions: inhale and exhale the smoke of tobacco or a drug
emit smoke or visible vapor from burning or heat
examples: He quit smoking after twenty years
She smokes only at social events
The chimney was smoking heavily
The volcano has been smoking for days

definitions: hold someone closely in one's arms, especially as a sign of affection
accept or support a belief, theory, or change willingly and enthusiastically
examples: The mother embraced her son after his long journey
Old friends embraced when they met again
The company embraced new technology to stay competitive
She embraced the opportunity to study abroad

definitions: exchange goods or services for other goods or services without using money
buy and sell goods and services as a commercial activity
examples: Children often trade cards with each other
I'll trade you my sandwich for your apple
He trades stocks on the exchange
The company trades with partners worldwide

definitions: aim or direct something at a particular person, group, or objective
select as an object of attention or attack
examples: The marketing campaign targets young professionals
The new policy targets environmental protection
Criminals often target elderly people for scams
The company was targeted by hackers

definitions: change the position, direction, or focus of something
adopt or exchange one thing for another
examples: Switch the light off before you leave
She switched the channel to watch the news
I decided to switch careers at forty
Let's switch seats so you can see better

definitions: become aware or conscious of something through the senses or mind
interpret or look at someone or something in a particular way
examples: Dogs can perceive sounds humans cannot hear
She perceived a change in his attitude
The public perceived him as arrogant
How do you perceive the current situation

definitions: follow the course or trail of someone or something, typically to find them
observe or monitor the course or progress of something over time
examples: The hunters tracked the deer through the forest
Police tracked the suspect using security cameras
We track our expenses using a spreadsheet
The app tracks your daily exercise routine

definitions: feel deep admiration for someone or something based on abilities, qualities, or achievements
show consideration or regard for someone's feelings, wishes, rights, or traditions
examples: I deeply respect her dedication to teaching
Students should respect their teachers
Please respect my privacy during this time
We must respect different cultural traditions

definitions: present or constitute a problem, danger, or challenge
assume a particular attitude or position for artistic purposes or photograph
examples: Climate change poses a serious threat to humanity
This situation poses difficult questions
The model posed for the fashion photographer
The family posed together for a portrait

definitions: leave one's job and cease to work, typically upon reaching a particular age
withdraw from a race, match, or competition, or go to bed
examples: She plans to retire at sixty-five
My father retired after forty years of service
The injured player had to retire from the match
Let's retire to the living room for coffee

definitions: fix or fasten something firmly so it cannot be moved or lost
succeed in obtaining something, especially with difficulty
examples: Secure all doors and windows before leaving
The captain secured the cargo with strong ropes
She managed to secure funding for her project
We need to secure a venue for the event

definitions: fasten or join one thing to another, typically using a clip, pin, or adhesive
examples: Please attach your resume to the email
She attached a note to the gift

definitions: give a loud, sharp cry or shout, typically expressing excitement, anger, or pain
examples: Don't yell at the children when they make mistakes
Fans yelled with excitement when their team scored

definitions: feel uncertain about something or consider something unlikely based on lack of conviction
examples: I doubt we'll finish the project on time
She began to doubt his sincerity

definitions: maintain something in its original or existing state to prevent decay or damage
keep safe from harm or injury and protect from danger
examples: Museums preserve artifacts for future generations
Salt helps preserve food for longer periods
We must preserve our natural resources
The law aims to preserve endangered species

definitions: present a proposal, application, or other document for consideration or judgment
accept or yield to a superior force or to the authority or will of another
examples: Please submit your application by Friday
Students must submit their essays on time
The rebels finally submitted to government forces
She refused to submit to their demands

definitions: observe and check the progress or quality of something over a period of time
examples: Nurses monitor patients' vital signs regularly
We need to monitor the situation closely

definitions: settle or find a solution to a problem, dispute, or contentious matter
decide firmly on a course of action with determination
examples: They met to resolve their differences peacefully
We need to resolve this issue quickly
She resolved to change her lifestyle
He resolved never to smoke again

definitions: make someone or something free of an unwanted person or thing
examples: We need to rid the house of mice
She finally rid herself of negative thoughts

definitions: tie or fasten something tightly together with rope, string, or similar material
impose a legal or moral obligation on someone to do something
examples: Bind the newspapers together with string
The nurse will bind your wound with gauze
The contract binds both parties to the agreement
Honor binds me to keep my promise

definitions: force something unwelcome or unfamiliar to be accepted or put in place
establish or apply something officially, especially a tax, fine, or ban
examples: Don't impose your beliefs on other people
I don't want to impose on your hospitality
The government imposed new taxes on luxury goods
The court imposed a heavy fine

definitions: share or exchange information, news, or ideas through speaking, writing, or other means
examples: We communicate mainly through email these days
It's important to communicate clearly with your team

definitions: differ in size, amount, degree, or nature from something else
introduce modifications or changes to make something less uniform
examples: Prices vary depending on the season
Teaching methods vary from school to school
Try to vary your diet for better nutrition
She varies her route to work each day

definitions: provide with light or lighting to make something visible or bright
make something start burning or become less heavy in weight
examples: Light the candles before dinner
Street lamps light the path at night
Can you light the fire
This suitcase is light enough to carry

definitions: strongly suggest the truth or existence of something without stating it directly
examples: Are you implying that I'm lying
His tone implied disappointment with the results

definitions: shape or force something straight into a curve or angle
interpret or modify rules to suit particular circumstances
examples: Bend your knees when lifting heavy objects
The strong wind bent the trees
Sometimes we need to bend the rules slightly
She won't bend her principles for anyone

definitions: engage in physical activity to sustain or improve health and fitness
use or apply a faculty, right, or process in a particular way
examples: I exercise at the gym three times a week
Doctors recommend exercising for thirty minutes daily
Citizens should exercise their right to vote
You need to exercise caution when driving

definitions: make a clear resonant or vibrating sound like that of a bell
call someone on the telephone
examples: The church bells ring every Sunday morning
The alarm clock rang at six o'clock
I'll ring you tomorrow about the meeting
Ring me if you need any help

definitions: intensify, increase, or further improve the quality, value, or extent of something
examples: This software will enhance your photos automatically
Exercise enhances both physical and mental health

definitions: move smoothly along a surface while maintaining continuous contact with it
gradually pass into a worse condition or lower level
examples: Children love to slide down the playground slide
She slid the letter under the door
Stock prices continued to slide throughout the day
Don't let your grades slide this semester

definitions: show or prove to be right or reasonable through evidence or argument
adjust the spacing between words in text to align with margins
examples: Can you justify your decision to quit
The evidence doesn't justify such harsh punishment
Please justify the text to the left margin
The document needs to be fully justified

definitions: successfully complete an academic degree, course of training, or high school
arrange in a series or according to a scale
examples: She will graduate from medical school next year
He graduated with honors from Harvard
The tax rates are graduated according to income
These measuring cups are graduated in ounces

definitions: regard with great respect and publicly acknowledge someone's merit or achievement
fulfill an obligation or keep an agreement
examples: We gather to honor our veterans today
The university will honor her with a special award
The bank refused to honor the check
We must honor our commitments

definitions: try earnestly or persistently to persuade someone to do something
feel a strong desire or impulse to do something
examples: I urge you to reconsider your decision
Doctors urge everyone to get vaccinated
She felt an urge to call her mother
He had to resist the urge to laugh

definitions: throw something somewhere lightly, easily, or casually
move or cause to move from side to side or back and forth
examples: Toss me the keys
She tossed the salad with dressing
The ship was tossed by the waves
He tossed and turned all night

definitions: indicate the faults of someone or something in a disapproving way
examples: The media constantly criticizes government policies
Don't criticize others without knowing the full story

definitions: allocate a job, duty, or responsibility to someone or designate for a specific purpose
examples: The teacher will assign homework every Friday
They assigned her to the marketing department

definitions: provide a book, newspaper, or text with pictures or diagrams
serve as an example that clarifies or explains something
examples: She illustrates children's books professionally
The artist illustrated the story beautifully
Let me illustrate my point with an example
This case illustrates the need for reform

definitions: find out how heavy someone or something is by using scales
assess the nature or importance of something, especially with a view to decision
examples: Please weigh these apples at the checkout
The nurse will weigh the baby
You need to weigh the pros and cons
The jury must weigh all the evidence

definitions: put things in a neat, attractive, or required order
organize or make plans for something to happen
examples: She arranged the flowers in a vase
Arrange the books alphabetically on the shelf
I'll arrange a meeting for next week
They arranged to meet at the restaurant

definitions: perform a series of mechanical or chemical operations on something to change or preserve it
examples: The factory processes raw materials into finished goods
It takes time to process all the applications

definitions: emerge or become apparent as a problem, opportunity, or situation
get or stand up from sitting, lying, or kneeling
examples: Problems may arise during implementation
New opportunities arise when you least expect them
He arose early to watch the sunrise
The audience arose when the judge entered
